attachments.title: Designers Code Differently
attachments.text: Should designers code? Yes, but not like developers.

text: <@U02618EV1>, which of those mentioned tools/programs do you find yourself gravitating toward? This Pixate tool looks like the more appealing, simpler option from my point of view. Curious to know what you think.
Framer looks pretty cool.
A buddy of mine who works in the Nike+ team loves Form but I haven't had the chance to play with it.

For me the main question is a what point the time spent on AE or any of these tools exceeds the time that would take a designer to code the thing instead of build something that then has to be translated and coded.

I'm wondering if tools like this are a better way to communicate ideas and intent on motion with developers. In the past I've more or less stood over their shoulder saying "do something like this" or just written a list of general descriptions of what I envision. Would you argue that learning how to code it right away and skipping the prototyping part might be a better option?
I think it depends on the person (designer) and the company they're working for.

If it's a smaller place and the person is curious about learning to make things then I would say it's a great move. If it's a bigger place and the designer learns to code b/c everyone is saying "you better learn to code" I think that may not work out. IMO, of course.

It also depends on the platform. Animations on the web are hard because they affect the content around them and performance big time. Whereas on native iOS and Android animating objects have a less effect on the content around them.
Sorry for the long rant. Been reading so much about animation I feel I could write a book now.

Yeah it doesn't seem necessary to do both design and dev, I'm just really into the idea of finding something to more effectively communicate interaction. I've always felt powerless to control any of that. I just signed up for a trial of Pixate, I'll keep you posted on how it goes... I'm kind of excited to see how this works out.
Cool
